NetBSD/hpcmips NetBSD/pmax binary Compatibility

This page contains information about NetBSD/hpcmips-pmax-arc-cobalt binary compatibility. At the package level, NetBSD/pmax, NetBSD/hpcmips, NetBSD/cobalt and NetBSD/arc are all compatible. Binary snapshot of "NetBSD 1.4U" is available. Userland binaries are compiled with "-mhard-float" flag.

NetBSD/cobalt binary compatibility

NetBSD/arc binary compatibility

NetBSD/pmax binary compatibility

  • Hardfloat 'mipsel' userland.
  • Softfloat 'mipselsf' userland and packages.
  • Softfloat 'mipselsf' userland, extra 'mipsel' libraries.

NetBSD/cobalt binary compatibility

NetBSD/cobalt is almost compatible with arc and pmax and hpcmips.

NetBSD/arc binary compatibility

NetBSD/arc is almost compatible with pmax and hpcmips. Only exception is disklabel (MAXPARTITIONS==16). Hpcmips's disklabel command is also incompatible with pmax, because it handles fdisk (MBR) partition table.

NetBSD/pmax binary compatibility

NetBSD/pmax userland binaries and packages are also little endian but use hardware floating point (which can be emulated) and incompatible function call rules (which prevents pmax and hpcmips binaries from using the same shared libraries).

Hardfloat 'mipsel' userland. (top)

Allows sharing of userland and packages with NetBSD/pmax, saving maintenance and distribution space, but at the cost of slower floating point performance.

Softfloat 'mipselsf' userland and packages. (top)

This gives the best performance, but cannot run dynamic NetBSD/pmax binaries.

Softfloat 'mipselsf' userland, extra 'mipsel' libraries. (top)

Softfloat 'mipselsf' userland, extra 'mipsel' libraries.
Two copies of each shared library are produced, one softfloat, one hardfloat, and ld.so modified to use correct type. This would allow both types of binaries to run, but would be a maintenance nightmare.

Up to NetBSD/hpcmips Port Page
